title: scotlands-25-best-loved-trees
story: THE Fortingall Yew, found growing in the churchyard of the Perthshire village which shares its name, is among the oldest trees in Europe.There is some debate about its age. Modern experts estimate the tree is between , and , years old, although others believe it could be a remnant of a post-Roman Christian site dating back , years. A figure of , to , years has also been suggested.According to folklore, Pontius Pilate ndash the Roman governor who oversaw the crucixion of Jesus ndash was born in its shade and played there as a child.One story suggests that Pilatersquos father was on a diplomatic mission to a Pictish king when news of his sonrsquos birth reached Fortingall, another that his pregnant we had been travelling with him and a third that the child was born after an illicit liaison with a local woman.More recently the legend has been credited as a hoax devised by Sir Donald Currie, a shipping magnate who bought the Glenlyon Estate in . A patron to writers such as Rudyard Kipling and Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Sir Donald is said to have invented the tale as a prank with help from his literary friends.The Dool Tree, Blairquhan Castle, AyrshireDool or dule trees were used as natural gallows for public hangings ndash and often displayed the corpse for some weeks afterwards. They were common on many estates until the mid-th century. The ancient sycamore that stands in the shadow of Blairquhan Castle is believed to be a dool tree planted in the th century during the reign of King James V of Scotland.Hawthorn Tree at Cawdor Castle and Gardens near NairnIt is said that around , William, rd Thane of Cawdor, set out to build a replacement castle on a less marshy site than its predecessor. To find a location, he followed instructions said to have come to him in a dream and loaded panniers of gold on the back of a donkey.William followed the animal as it roamed across his lands. When night fell, it rested under a tree on a higher and rockier site close to the steep-sided Allt Dearg.The castle was built on that spot with the unique quirk that it was constructed around the tree. This subsequently became a feature of part of the cellar, known since as ldquoThe Hawthorn Room.Legend has it that the tree has magical qualities which have on more than one occasion saved the castle from disaster.Modern scientic analysis has revealed that the tree died in approximately , most likely as a result of being deprived of light because the castle had been built around it. The other surprise  It is a holly tree, not a hawthorn. It still stands in the cellar to this day.Champion trees, ious locationsScotland boasts many champion trees: the largest, tallest and the exceptional. There is a Champion Tree Trail at Mount Stuart on Bute which features a Corsican pine, an evergreen coner planted around  which has grown to ft .Ardkinglas Woodland Garden at Cairndow, Argyll has an impressive collection of champion trees, including ldquothe mightiest coner in Europe, a European silver fir with an almost ftgirth.Dawyck Botanic Garden near Peebles is home to some of Britainrsquos oldest and tallest trees including a European silver fir planted in  during the reign of King Charles II. There are Douglas firs that date back to , grown from the original seed sent home by the famous botanist David Douglas.The Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh has a striking paperbark maple which is easy to identy, even in winter thanks to its eye-catching form of self-exfoliation. As the old sheaves of the copper-red bark die, they peel themselves off revealing the young, smooth bark beneath.The changeable colours of the treersquos leaves are equally dazzling. Starting out as orange in the spring, they become a pinkish-brown and then yellow, before finally turning deep green.By late autumn, the leaves have taken on a deep red hue, complementing its peeling, coppery bark. The paperbark maple was first collected in China at the turn of the th century by botanist Ernest Henry Wilson.Bicycle Tree near Brig orsquo Turk, TrossachsDating from the late th century, the so-called ldquoBicycle Tree is a sycamore reputed to have self-seeded beside the scrap heap of the village blacksmith in Brig orsquo Turk. As it grew, it absorbed ndash or swallowed up ndash several metal objects, including a bicycle and, reputedly, a shiprsquos anchor and chain.There is a fable about a young man conscripted to the First World War who left his bicycle hanging over a branch. Some say he never came back ndash orhe didfound that the tree had claimed the two-wheeled steed as its own. Today all that remains are the handlebars sticking out of the trunk.William Wallace Yew, Elderslie, RenfrewshireTwo symbolic trees once stood side-by-side: the Wallace Oak and the Wallace Yew. Now only the latter remains. Some doubt has been cast on the age, yet parish records from the s refer to it as ldquothis ancient tree. It stands near to where William Wallace is reputed to have been born in .Robertrsquos Brucersquos Yew, Loch LomondWilliam Wallace isnrsquot the only Scottish hero to have his own yew. Perched on a rocky outcrop on Loch Lomond, this ancient tree is where Robert the Bruce is said to have sheltered from his enemies in  while recounting tales of valour to keep his troopsrsquo spirits up.Wollemi pines, Inverewe Garden and Estate, Poolewe, Ross-shireInverewe boasts the worldrsquos most northerly grove of a Jurassic tree. Wollemi pine was thought to have died out two million years ago, but the species was discovered in Australia in the early s. Eight were planted at Inverewe in .Nettyrsquos Tree, Eriskay, Outer HebridesNewly crowned as Scotlandrsquos Tree of the Year  in a Woodland Trust poll, this spruce known as ldquoNettyrsquos Tree was, until recently, the only tree on Eriskay. It was planted more than  years ago by the poet, priest and land rights activist Father Allan McDonald.Netty MacDonald lived on the nearby croft and encouraged the islandrsquos children to play on the tree as their cries and laughter reminded her of her own family who had grown up and moved away to work. Netty died aged  in . Her daughter now lives on the croft and continues the tradition.Rizziorsquos Chestnut, Melville Castle Hotel, near DalkeithAccording to folklore, this Spanish chestnut tree was planted for Mary Queen of Scots by her Italian private secretary David Rizzio as a token of his love for her. The Queen responded by planting five oak trees along the drives which also survive to this day.A less public declaration may have been prudent. After rumours spread that the pair were lovers, a group of outraged Scottish nobles stabbed Rizzio  times. His brutal murder took place in front of the seven-months-pregnant queen at Holyrood Palace in .The Caledonian ForestMuch of the Highlands and what is now the Cairngorms National Park was once covered with the Caledonian Forest estimated in its heyday, around , BC, to have spanned . million hectares, about a fth of Scotlandrsquos land mass.By , BC, however, as the climate became wetter and windier, the forest was reduced signicantly. It continued to shrink in size from then onwards largely due to human intervention.Today the Caledonian Forest exists in  remnants. The Scots pine trees found here are directly descended from the native pinewoods that grew around , BC and once formed the westernmost outpost of the Boreal Forest in Europe.Beneath the vast forest canopy, the likes of wild boar, lynx, brown bears and grey wolves ndash now extinct in the wild in Scotland ndash roamed.The Caledonian Forest is still home to some of the rarest wildle in the British Isles, including mountain hare, pine marten, red squirrel, Scottish wildcats, capercaillie, crested tit and Scottish crossbill.It was revealed last month that a poundm Endangered Landscapes Programme has selected the Caledonian Forest to be the focus of a key restoration project ndash along with seven other major regeneration schemes ndash to restore Europersquos most threatened environments.Mallochrsquos Oak, Strathallan Castle, PerthshireThere is a dark history tied to the Mallochrsquos Oak in the grounds of Strathallan Castle. It is said that during a famine the local miller, Malloch, hoarded flour and grain instead of distributing it to the starving locals. He was strung up from this tree as punishment.Copper beech tree, Drummond Castle Gardens, PerthshireThe formal terraced gardens include a copper beech tree planted by Queen Victoria to commemorate her visit in .The Camperdown Elm, Camperdown Park, DundeeA contorted weeping elm discovered in woods near Dundee in , it is thought to have been re-planted near what was then the Earl of Camperdownrsquos new mansion house and is now within the cityrsquos Camperdown Park.Flodden Tree, The Hirsel Estate near Coldstream, BerwickshireThis sycamore on the Hirsel Estate in the Borders is believed to have been planted in tribute to the Scottish dead at the Battle of Flodden in .Napoleonrsquos Tree, Ecclefechan, DumfriesshireDuring his final days on the Atlantic island of St Helena, Napoleon Bonaparte befriended British Army surgeon Archibald Arnott. Two days before he died, Napoleon gave instructions that no British doctor except Arnott should touch him.A weeping willow tree was Napoleonrsquos favourite spot for contemplation on the island and he asked to be buried under its shade. This wish was fulfilled when he died in  and Napoleon was interred there until being repatriated to France almost  years later.Arnott took a cutting from the tree, planting it on hishome to Ecclefechan, where it still grows in the grounds of the Kirkconnel Hall Hotel.The ldquoFilo Pastry Tree, Logan Botanic Gardens near StranraerThis impressive specimen of Polylepis australis ndash the largest of its kind in the UK ndash got its nickname from a Stranraer Academy pupil who compared the flaky bark to the filo pastry on a spring roll. Originating from South America, its peeling bark traps air to keep the tree warm at night.Redwood Avenue, Benmore Botanic Garden, ArgyllVisitors enter the gardens through the majestic Redwood Avenue which was planted in , a time when the American Civil War was at its height and Queen Victoria was on the throne. These towering Sequoiadendron giganteum are now around  metres high.Birnam Oak and Birnam Sycamore, PerthshireThe Birnam Oak and its neighbour the Birnam Sycamore are thought to be the sole surviving trees of the great forest that once straddled the banks of the River Tay. This is immortalised in Shakespearersquos Macbeth as the Birnam Wood.The ldquoBig Tree, Kirkwall, OrkneyTo be fair, the ldquoBig Tree is not actually that lofty. Rather, this -year-old sycamore is much beloved among Orcadians due to its prominent position on Kirkwallrsquos main street making it a popular meeting spot. It was voted Scotlandrsquos Tree of the Year .The giants of Reelig Glen, InvernessReelig Glen boasts some of Britainrsquos tallest trees: a Douglas fir that, when measured in , came in at .fta larch measuring .fta .ft-highNorway spruce and a lime tree which stands at .ft . The Dughall Mor ndash the big dark stranger ndash a Douglas fir planted in  also grows there.Queen Maryrsquos Thorn, St Andrews UniversityA hawthorn said to have been planted by Mary, Queen of Scots in the s grows in the grounds of St Maryrsquos College at St Andrews University. Interestingly, Moray House Garden at Edinburgh University once had its own Queen Maryrsquos Thorn, believed to have been lost in the mid-th century as the teacher training college expanded.Stevensonrsquos Yew, EdinburghThe yew was a favourite play spot for Robert Louis Stevenson - author of Treasure Island, Kidnapped and the Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde - as a child visiting his grandfather in the Colinton area of Edinburgh. It is said the marks of a swing are still visible on its branches.Robert Kirkrsquos Fairy Tree, AberfoyleReverend Robert Kirk wrote the book The Secret Commonwealth of Elves, Fauns And Fairies in filled with stories about those who claimed to have had contact with these mythical beings, including Kirk himself.He believed that the Doon Hill in Aberfoyle was a gateway to the world of the fairies. Kirk died in  after collapsing while visiting the hill at night. It is likely he suffered a heart attack, yet rumours swirled among local people that he been carried away by the fairies for revealing their secrets.Doon Hill is also known as ldquoFairy Knowe or ldquoDun Sithean and according to legend Kirkrsquos soul is still trapped inside a lone Scots pine. Today, people hang ribbons and messages around the trees in this area to ward off illness and bad luck or commemorate a loved one.Beech Avenue, Achnacarry, Inverness-shireThe story goes that Donald ldquoThe Gentle Lochiel Cameron heard about the arrival in Scotland of Charles Edward Stuart ndash Bonnie Prince Charlie ndash while planting this avenue of beech trees on his estate at Achnacarry, just prior to the Jacobite rising of .The inaugural Scottish Tree Festival organised by Discover Scottish Gardens features more than  tree-themed events and runs until December .
