title: scotlands-most-senior-trade-union-figure-faces-internal-unrest-over-outside-earnings
story: A private meeting of the Scottish Trades Union Congresslast week included a discussion on general secretary Grahame Smith, who is believed to have boosted his pay packet by around pound, for sitting on Government-linked boards.The STUCrsquos governing body is now reviewing its procedures for membership of external bodies.The Herald on Sunday contacted some of the STUCrsquos largest affiliated unions about the controversy, but many did not provide a comment.However, a spokesperson for the GMB Scotland union, which is a key part of the STUC, said: "On numerous occasions we have raised our concerns about transparency and accountability in the running of the STUC. This is to defend the jobs and conditions of the staff we represent in the STUC and to ensure the organisations future ability to campaign effectively on behalf of all its affiliate members. We will continue to address those concerns through the internal processes of the STUC."As the umbrella body for nearly  affiliated trade unions, the STUC represents around , workers and acts as the voice of organised labour north of the border.However, critics have questioned the STUCrsquos independence under Mr Smithrsquos leadership after it emerged the body received over % of its funding from the SNP Government last year.Mr Smith, who became general secretary in , has also faced sniping from within the trade union world over the way he has topped up an STUC remuneration package thought to be close to pound,.As a board member of jobs quango Scottish Enterprise between  and , Mr Smith is believed to have received up to pound, in fees.He currently has three additional posts which attract payment. As a board member of Skills Development Scotland he is entitled to between pound, and pound, a year and qualies for a pound, a year salary bump as a board member of the Scottish Qualications Authority. He can also receive a daily rate as a member of the Enterprise and Skills Enterprise Board.Mr Smith was also briefly the interim chair of the Glasgow Colleges Regional Board, for which he received pound,, but he did not not receive any remuneration for his time on the UK Commission on Employment and Skills.The payments issue was raised last week at a meeting of the STUCrsquos general council, which is comprised of union representatives.At one point, staff left the room so that affiliates could discuss matters in private, a session that lasted around two hours.It is understood unhappiness was expressed about the money Mr Smith had received since  for sitting on boards, the transparency of appointments, as well as the lack of an in-house register of interest.Others at the meeting said they were not singling out any one inidual as previous general secretaries had also sat on external boards.However, a trade union source said Mr Smith was becoming ldquomarginalised.The row also comes amid a debate within the trade union movement over male trade unionists hogging multiple posts.In a statement to this newspaper, STUC President Lynn Henderson said:ldquoThe STUC engagement with a range of public bodies is reported every year in the General Council report to our Annual Congress. The General Council is currently reviewing our processes and procedures. We are considering how these can be improved to ensure that the considerable influence the trade union movement has on such bodies and on public policy can be further enhanced.ldquoIn serving on public bodies, the General Secretary is following the same practice as his predecessors. I believe that in doing so, the General Secretary is always focused on advancing the interests of unions and working people. Grahame has served as General Secretary for  years and is widely respected throughout the trade union movement and wider civil society. During that period the STUC has continued to exert considerable influence over the direction of economic and social policy in Scotland.

title: snp-run-glasgow-council-snubs-swinney-by-removing-his-name-from-teacher-pay-letter
story: The Deputy First Minister initially co-signed the draft communication to teachers, but Glasgow city council snubbed him and put it out from their own education convener.Labour MSP Iain Gray said: "With John Swinney becoming increasingly unpopular with teachers, it is no surprise that SNP-run Glasgow City Council deleted his signature from the letter.Mr Swinney is embroiled in a bitter row with the trade unions over their demand for teachers pay to be increased by %.Council umbrella group COSLA, with the support of the Scottish Government, has offered % and strike action is on the horizon.The Government has also suggested that an overhaul of the main grade scale, coupled with the % rise, would result in some teachers getting a boost in excess of %.However, the disagreement was aggravated after the Government and COSLA agreed to go over the heads of the unions by sending a ldquojoint communication directly to teachers about the offer.The Education Secretary wanted teachers to hear his side of the pay proposal before they voted in a consultative ballot.The draft letter was co-signed by Mr Swinney and Tory councillor Gail Macgregor, who is COSLArsquos resources spokesperson, and stated:ldquoWe firmly believe that this is a fair offer which demonstrates that both Local Government and the Scottish Government value the teaching profession. We are disappointed that it has been rejected by the teacher unions.ldquoThe teacher unionsrsquo claim for % in a single year cannot be achieved. It is simply unaffordable, and the unions have been told this since their claim was submitted at the start of the year.They also said the pay offer and the grading restructuring amounted to a poundm investment in teachers.However, when teachers in Glasgow received the letter by email, the names of Mr Swinney and Ms Macgregor had vanished. The signature of SNP councillor Chris Cunningham, who is the convener for Education, Skills  Early Years, appeared instead.The wording was the same as the initial draft put together by COSLA and the Government, apart from an extra paragraph at the beginning:ldquoCOSLA Leaders agreed that a joint letter from the Scottish Government and COSLA should be prepared and sent out to teachers explaining the pay offer to them.ldquoThe information below is from the Scottish Government and COSLA which talks to the offer on the table and I would be gratefulyou could share it with teachers in your school.Glasgow was a Labour bastion at a local authority level for decades, but the SNP won control of the council for the first time last year.Around , teachers, many of whom are based in Glasgow, protested against Mr Swinney over the pay standoff at a rally in the city recently.Placards included lsquoSwinney is a ninny and lsquoEbenezer Swinneyrsquo, which an education source said was an indication of the hostility to the SNP heavyweight by teachers.A Council spokeswoman said: ldquoOur City Convener for Education, Skills  Early Years, Councillor Chris Cunningham has sent a letter to schools which includes information from the Scottish Government and Cosla on the teachers pay award proposal.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has worked with COSLA to put in place the best teacher pay deal in the UK for -.It is important that the component parts of the deal are explained in detail so that teachers have a full understanding of the proposals on the table.

title: theresa-may-faces-struggle-to-keep-brexit-plans-on-track-amid-tory-tensions
story: With the shock resignation of pro-Europe transport minister Jo Johnson continuing to cause ructions in Tory ranks, the Prime Minister is running out of time to seal an EU exit deal.Hope of getting the Cabinet to sign off on Brexit deal proposals this week appeared to be rapidly receding as it was reported the EU had rejected UK plans for an independent arbitration clause that could allow the UK to quit a backstop deal on the Northern Ireland border.With both pro and anti-withdrawal Tories becoming more vocal in their opposition to Mrs Mayrsquos stance, arch-Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg called on the PM to change tack.He urged Mrs May to end the deadlock by paying the EU pound billion to secure a ldquono deal plus arrangement with the bloc after withdrawal.Writing in the Mail on Sunday, Mr Rees-Mogg, who heads the influential European Research Group of  Tory MPs, suggested offering the financial deal to Brussels in order toldquomake our departure as amicable as possible.Previously critical of the pound billion orce bill the UK is set to pay the EU, Mr Rees-Mogg wrote: ldquoIt is time for convinced Brexiteers like me to compromise.ldquoSo, at this late hour in the negotiations, we would like to make a new, generous offer to break the deadlock, to achieve a lsquoNo Deal Plusrsquo.ldquoIt would cost us money but it would finally dispel the lsquocrash outrsquo Project Fear nightmare scenarios.A Government source told the Press Association: ldquoThe end part of negotiations were always going to be tough.ldquoThere are a number of issues that need to be worked through on the Northern Ireland backstop and these are the most dficult.ldquoThey include ensuring that,it is ever needed, it is not permanent and there is a mechanism to ensure the UK could not be held in the arrangement indefinitely.Well done to @JoJohnsonUK on standing up for what he believes in. He was a fantastic Minister to work with whilst we were at the DfE. Itrsquos a sad loss for Gvt, but Brexit is above party politics. https:t.co icoTQDFvmdash Justine GreeningNovember , Former Cabinet minister Justine Greening, who shares Mr Johnsonrsquos view that a fresh referendum is needed, called on Tories to oppose the PMrsquos Chequers proposals.She told The Observer: ldquoThe parliamentary deadlock has been clear for some time. Itrsquos crucial now for Parliament to vote down this plan, because it is the biggest giveaway of sovereignty in modern times.The view was echoed by Brexiteer Tory MP Andrew Bridgen who told a meeting of the Bruges Group: ldquoIf we canrsquot chuck Chequers then itrsquos time to chuck the Prime Minister.Tory Brexiteer Steve Baker and DUP Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson wrote in The Sunday : ldquoIf the Government makes the historic mistake of prioritising placating the EU over establishing an independent and whole UK, then, regrettably, we must vote against the deal.Brexiteers have insisted that the UK should not get involved with a potentially permanent backstop customs union agreement with the EU as the price of avoiding a hard border in Northern Ireland.

title: silhouettes-of-tommies-projected-on-to-famous-uk-landmarks
story: The Tommies illuminated Marble Arch, Tate Modern, HMS Belfast, Warwick Castle, the Angel of the North, the Tyne Bridge, Titanic Belfast, Cardf Castle and Edinburgh Castle.The silhouettes have appeared all over the UK since the campaign launched in February, commemorating the British and Commonwealth troops who died in the First World War whilst also raising funds for military charities.General the Lord Dannatt, patron of There But Not There and former chief of the general staff, said: ldquoAs we reach  years since the Armistice, it is vital that we reflect on the sacrice made by an entire generation of servicemen and women.ldquoThese wonderful landmarks coming together provide a remarkable representation of the nation doing exactly just that.ldquoWe have been incredibly moved by the overwhelming public support that we have received across the country, which has led to more than pound million raised for military and mental health charities.ldquoHowever, our journey doesnrsquot stop here we need the publicrsquos backing more than ever in raising funds to support our veterans in crisis.ldquoMental health remains a crucial issue and we hope people will see these poignant silhouettes and be inspired to buy their own Tommy to both remember the fallen and to help those that continue to struggle today.

title: why-we-should-all-commemorate-armistice-day-2018
story: Mark Bibbey, Poppyscotland chief executive, said: ldquoAt am this morning, the nation will stand in silent reflection as we mark Remembrance Sunday. Of course, today has added signicance as it is exactly  years since the signing of the Armistice that brought the First World War to an end.ldquoIt was a conflict which saw almost one million British and Commonwealth soldiers lose their lives many more seriously damaged by physical or mental trauma and which changed our society and how we live our lives in so many ways.ldquoAs we pass such a signicant milestone some have questioned the continued relevance of the annual act of Remembrance. However, I believe that Remembrance remains relevant today and into the future for two important reasons.ldquoFirstly, becausewe do not continue to acknowledge the lessons of the past then we risk repeating them in the future and, secondly, because the men and women of our Armed Forces continue to selflessly put themselves in harmrsquos way in order to defend our freedoms which so many have paid the ultimate price to preserve.ldquoWe at Poppyscotland believe that no-one should be disadvantaged by their time in the service and that is why our work in providing those in our Armed Forces community with le-changing support remains so vitally important today.ldquoIt is for these reasons that I think that Armistice Day, Remembrance Sunday and the Scottish Poppy Appeal must and will retain the upmost relevance well beyond this yearrsquos centenary.Victoria Wallace, director general of Commonwealth War Graves Commission, said: ldquoWe are proud to be s of the final resting places of the Commonwealth men and women who died in the two world wars, as well as commemorating the thousands with no known grave.ldquoWe hope everyone will take a moment at this special centenary to find their local CWGC site, and make a small pilgrimage to honour the men and women who gave their all. With war graves or memorials in almost every town and village in the UK and more than  countries and territories, we hope to see more people than ever on Remembrance Sunday.Erskine chief executive Wing Commander Ian Cumming MBE said: ldquoArmistice Day is a signicant and poignant event for everyone at Erskine, but for our veterans in particular. We remember those who made the ultimate sacrice, during a century of conflicts from the First World War to the present day.ldquoWe support our veteran residents who served during the Second World War, as they each reflect inidually on what they saw and the friends they lost. And, of course, Erskine staff and beneficiaries who saw fighting and peacekeeping in more recent conflicts also come together to support each other. We reflect on what we have learned about the devastating physical and psychological effects of war on iniduals and families. Most importantly at this time of year, Erskine remembers those who gave their lives, so that we might live in freedom. We pledge to honour their memory by caring for those heroes who did come home.Justine Baynes, director at SSAFA, the Armed Forces charity, said: ldquoSSAFA, the Armed Forces charity, was the only national, tri-service charity around during World War One. At the outbreak of the war, SSAFA was called upon by the Government to look after the families left behind.ldquoTo mark the centenary of the Armistice, SSAFA is encouraging families to keep our nationrsquos history alive, by sharing their stories of World War One, so they will never be forgotten.ldquoThe further we move away from the conflict, the more important it becomes to keep the stories of bravery and courage alive, and commemorate those who gave up their lives for our country.ldquoThis Sunday, take a moment to remember those who lost their lives during the First World War and in each conflict ever since.Sue Freeth, chief executive of Combat Stress, the UKrsquos leading charity for veteransrsquo mental health, said: ldquoI will be laying a wreath at the Cenotaph on Remembrance Sunday. Irsquom sure it will be a very moving experience. I will be extremely proud to march alongside veterans and colleagues from Combat Stress. Itrsquos important to remember not only those servicemen and women we have lost but also those whofrom conflicts needing support, care and treatment.

title: sunnyside-up-the-coolest-brunches-in-scotland
story: . Partick Duck ClubPartick, GlasgowThe coolest place to have brunch these days isnrsquot Finnieston, but Partick, where there is a restaurant that makes all other brunches look unimaginative. You may have your ideas about what brunch fodder is, but the Partick Duck Club takes it to a new dimension with its Duck Leg and Nduja hash or their Orkney Crab  Poached Duck Egg on Toast with Avocado and Cregraveme Fraiche. Plus,yoursquore in the mood, and starting off the day with a party, or the hair of a dog, it delivers an excellent Bloody Mary or a Gin Mary. Itrsquos relaxed, informal, cosy ndash but as Joanna Blythman, who gave the food . , has put it, ldquothe cooking is seriously polished. They even open at am for breakfast ndash though breakfast, of course, is too small a concept to apply to anything served at Partick Duck Club.. Cafeacute GandolfiMerchant City, GlasgowIt was a trendsetter back in the day ndash now itrsquos an irresistible classic, with its rustic wooden chairs and encyclopedic menu. Forget shakshuka and brunch in timeless style from a menu that goes on and on, but which includes eggs cocotte, Aberdeen Smoked Haddie and dishes with Stornoway black pudding. Itrsquos said that Cafeacute Gandolfi, which opened in , imported the cityrsquos first cappuccino machine.. ToastLeith, EdinburghToast describes itself as a wine cafeacute, soreally good natural or biodynamic wine is what you want with your lateish brunch, then herersquos the place to head. ldquoA cool and comfortable hub for all things wine and coffee related, is how Zak Han its founder describes it. Take up a spot by the window looking out over the Shore and try their shakshuka or huevos rancheros, before finishing off with one of their cakes which look untouchably beautul, yet taste ine. Andthe tables are all booked, remember the Shore, like all trendy spots, is spoiled for choice ndash you only need to walk a few steps to find another top brunch provider.. Singl-endGarnethill and Merchant City, GlasgowNo longer is there just a single Singl-end. There are now two ndash andyour idea of a heavenly brunch involves some seriously good bread, then look no further than one of these joints. They even have bread ldquomenus, which include the likes of sourdough, Altamura, sweet potato and almond, bread of the day and others. But itrsquos not all about the bakes ndash here, they also make their own pork and fennel bangers, serving them with cannellini beans and chilli, and a heavenly vegan breakfast that includes sweet potato rounds and avocado and chilli smash. Plus, their boho vibe and leather armchairs make them the perfect place to relax. One Glasgow food blogger described it as ldquoa little slice of chilled out heaven on a Sunday morning". Open at am on Sundays.. Bird And BearCity Centre, DundeeThe home of the hip-hop brunch. Yes, that is an official thing. On both Saturdays and Sundays from am-pm, Bird And Bear gives brunch the music vibe it deserves. This is the place for for those who like a chilled, no-rush Sunday of listening to some old-school sounds, while chowing down on dishes from a menu that includes such highlights as coconut and quinoa pancakes, baked pimento eggs and the steak breakfast. You can even revive with an alcoholic milkshake. Plus the deacutecor, with its hammered copper, birdcages and palm wallpaper, is a paradise of cool.. The Tatha Bar And KitchenDundee WaterfrontYes, brunch is about the food, but itrsquos also the location, the view, being transported ndash and Tatha Bar And Kitchen, the VArsquos brunch venue, with its huge glass windows and balcony over the Tay certainly works those factors. Here, you can combine a tour of the iconic museum with a stop-off for an open breakfast burrito or a smoked Perthshire salmon royal. Chef Brian Canale runs a scratch kitchen which means everything is made fresh each morning. Be warned, though, the VA is still mobbed at the weekends, and yoursquore best advised to book.. Mountain CafeacuteAviemore, CairngormsThere are times when, alluring as an early start on the mountain is, what you crave is a good, big lazy brunch. For those days there is always the Mountain Cafeacute, which opens for breakfast at .am and keeps on serving it throughout the day. Owner-chef Kirsten Gilmour, who describes herself as ldquoa Kiwi in the Cairngorms, brings her antipodean style to the dishes. Itrsquos hard to look further than the All Day Brekki or the Veg Brekkie, delivering everything you could want on a plate. As might be expected, this is about hearty food ndash the kind of breakfast that might keep you going as you tackle the great outdoors.. Sanddollar CafeacuteBeach front, AberdeenWhat better way to spend a Sunday morning than a bracing walk along the sands followed by a pile of pancakes  Beach and brunch are a match made in heaven, and this cafeacute on the esplanade, with a wide breakfast menu, is a huge draw for families who want to chill and eat. When the sun is shining you can sit out on wooden tables. Or, when the wind gets up, cosy up inside and enjoy its bright, airy atmosphere. Opens at .am.. Cafe SiaBroadford, SkyeIn a cosy white bungalow at the foot of the Red Cuillin hills is a cafeacute that does it all ndash brunch, pizza, seafood, but most of all the best coffee, so they claim, on the island. Sia means six, and thatrsquos the number of menu options it offers for brunch, including the all-day breakfast, eggs florentine or benedict, pancakes and the Siabatta, a ciabatta with breakfast filling. Its barista, Craig, sources coffee beans and small batch roasts them in the ldquowee red Samiac drum. Open from .am.. Mhor Balquhidder, The TrossachsSometimes a brunch is just what you need to interrupt a journey north or south through the mountains, or as a reviving feast the day after some serious hill-walking. Mhor , one of the sister venues to fine-dining star Monachyle Mhor is there for those moments. Itrsquos a motel, restaurant, bar and cafeacute and its breakfasts, served from am until .am, are beyond moreish ndash though itrsquos hard to imagine anyone would be wanting any more after theyrsquove eaten a ldquobig breakfast that includes all the regulars plus Stornoway black pudding, haggis and potato scone.. Fairmont HotelSt Andrews, FeYou could call this a brunch, but really its more of a branquet, including everything from a carvery to an extraordinary patisserie selection. The word branquet isnt in common use just yet, but really it should be, so we all know the dference between a regular brunch and the feast thats being provided here. The hotel ran its International Brunches over the summer, but they were so popular they were extended all the way to Christmas. All of this in the glamour of the hotelrsquos Atrium under the glow of their George Singer lighting installation. Priced at pound. per adult and pound per child, from pm-pm.. Fruin FarmLoch Lomond National ParkWhat could be a better way of brunching with kids than to do it on a farm  Followed by a wander round the farmyard, some pond dipping or a llama trek, and a gaze at the views down the glen  If you want to know precisely where every bit of your brunch has come from ndash and maybe see something like it wandering around outside ndash then this is the place to eat. Everything, they say, has been raised and slaughtered in the UK, none of it intensively farmed not Puddledub bacon, Katy Rodgers natural yogurt, Stornoway black pudding. Breakfast here finishes at .am, so yoursquore looking at an early start ndash but chances are the kids have had you up since dawn anyway., Birnam brasserieGleneagles, AuchterarderBrunch at the Birnam Brasserie at Gleneagles is so special it only happens on the first Sunday of the month ndash which tells you a little about just how swanky it is. This is destination brunching at its most decadent, with live jazz playing the background, a Bellini station and an ice-cream cart, and deacutecor that evokes a Grand Parisian cafe. All the brunch classics are there, but also the croques monsieur, the steak and eggs with frites and a self-serve cold bar brimming with shellfish, seafood, charcuterie, cheese and salads. .-.pm, prices from pound per adult and pound per child. Yes, its another branquet ndash beyond indulgence.. The Glad Cafeacute, Southside, GlasgowWhere southside creative types go not only to brunch, but hang out, listen to music, talk about art, watch film, write a few poems or log on to their wi. Glad Cafeacute also happens to offer one of the best vegan and vegetarian brunches in Glasgow, courtesy of Hen Of The Woods ndash also the team behind The Hug And Pint ndash on both Saturdays and Sundays, am until pm. Middle Eastern flavours, Asian influences, sourdough bread from social enterprise, the Freedom Bakery. Think dishes like poached eggs with salted yoghurt and chilli brown butter tofu chettinad, washed down with a cup of Dear Green Coffee and a good dollop of social conscience.. The PantryStockbridge, EdinburghWhen the Pantry launched in  it became the definition of brunch in Edinburgh, leading the way on what you can do with an egg, a pancake or a waffle. The Sunday Times said their eggrsquos benedict was ldquoreason alone to come to Edinburgh. It still remains hard to beat and repeatedly pops up on lists of best brunches and breakfasts in the UK. Run by husband-and-we team, Chris and Charlotte Thompson, and described as an urban farm shop ndash it serves locally-sourced produce. Itrsquos also nestled in an elegant spot in the New Town, right on Royal Circus. Open daily for brunch from am to pm.. VestaWest End, EdinburghThe indulgent brunch with a conscience. Social Bitersquos Home has been relaunched, refurbished and rethought as something new and fresh, and on Sundays its offering its Bubbles and Brunch. The restaurant still works on the same principle ndash homeless people train and work there and customers are encouraged to ldquopay forward meals for the homeless. Itrsquos a quality brunch too ndash offering buttermilk pancakes, avocado on toast with salsa and watercress or baked eggs with cheddar, spinach, tomatoes and black beans, as well as some fizz on the side.. GnomSouthside, GlasgowBreakfast bao, or steamed Asian buns, are one of the chief foodie draws of this Southside brunch venue, and they are good ndash filled with crispy pork belly or mushrooms, gochujang ketchup and eggs. And who could not be tempted by their French toast ice cream sandwiches  Head there for a blether over brunch by its big, bright windows. Itrsquos hipster central, but irresistible.. The Gardenerrsquos CottageCalton Hill, EdinburghFor a brunch thatrsquos about the locally-sourced greens, herbs and heritage carrots as well as the eggs, sausages and kippers, this intimate restaurant in a converted cottage in the gardens at the foot of Calton Hill is the go-to destination. Itrsquos not, as Joanna Blythman, once commented without its middle-class ldquoaffectation ndash but its brunch really does feel fresh from the garden. If, however, the big foodie love affair in your le is bread ndash and you also like your brunch a bit more casual and Scandi ndash then therersquos sister cafeacute Quay Commons in Leith. Brioche heaven.

title: the-harsh-armistice-terms
story: These included: The cessation of hostilities within six hours. Evacuation of France, Belgium, Luxembourg, and Alsace-Lorraine within  days, the sick and wounded left behind for Allies to care for. The withdrawal of German forces to behind the Rhine and Allied occupation of the Rhineland. The preservation of infrastructure. Surrender of mateacuteriel: , artillery pieces, , machine guns, , minenwerfers , , aircraft , , railway locomotives, , railcars and , trucks. Immediate release of all Allied prisoners of war, without reciprocity. All minefields on land and sea to be identied. Eventual reparations. However, the relaxation of the naval blockade of Germany which had brought widespread starvation and death was not agreed to.Following the Armistice the occupation of the Rhineland took place. The occupying armies consisted of American, Belgian, British, and French forces.

title: events-held-across-the-uk-and-around-the-world-to-commemorate-armistice-day-centenary
story: The festival commemorated all those who have lost their lives in conflicts and marked  years since the First World War ended.The Queen was joined by the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, and the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.A series of events will take place across the UK today to mark  years since the end of the First World War.The Prince of Wales will once again lead the nation in honouring the countrys war dead during the national service of remembrance.The Queen has asked Charles to lay a wreath at the Cenotaph in Whitehall on her behalf ndash the second successive year he will perform the duty. The Queen will watch from the balcony of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office building, as she did last year.After Charles has laid a wreath, other floral tributes will be left by members of the royal family, senior figures from the government, including Prime Minister Theresa May, and opposition party leaders and other figures from national le.The SNPrsquos Westminster leader, Ian Blackford MP, will lay a wreath on behalf of the SNP and Plaid Cymru that will include the words ldquoLest we forget in English, Gaelic and Welsh.Blackford said: ldquoI am honoured to be able to attend the ceremony today at the Cenotaph, and to lay a wreath in what is only a small gesture in gratitude for the sacrices our service personnel made during the First World War. On this day, for them, we fall silent and remember."The First Minister will lay a wreath at the Stone of Remembrance at Edinburgh City Chambers before attending the service at St Giles Cathedral. Later in the day she is going to a special service at Glasgow Cathedral marking  years since the Armistice.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "Remembrance Sunday is an opportunity for people in Scotland to join with others across the world to commemorate those who made the ultimate sacrice in conflicts during the last century."It allows us a chance to honour the memory of those who gave their lives, while also paying tribute to our veterans and those who continue to serve today.ldquoThis year of course has added poignancy as it marks  years since the signing of the Armistice that ended the First World War."The laying of a wreath is a small but signicant tribute, and I am privileged to be able to do so on behalf of the people of Scotland."For the first time, a German leader will lay a wreath at the Cenotaph in London, with President Frank-Walter Steinmeier performing the duty on behalf of his nation in a historic act of reconciliation.Families whose ancestors died or were injured in the First World War will be remembering their relatives as they take part in a ldquopeoples procession".A total of , people, chosen by ballot, will have the opportunity to pay their respects to all those who served in the First World War by taking part in the Nations Thank You procession past the Cenotaph.Church bells will ring out today as they did at the end of the First World War ndash and a Westminster Abbey service will be held along with others in Glasgow, Cardf and Belfast, to give thanks for peace and those who ed.This afternoon a concert will take place at Edinburgh Napier Universitys Craiglockhart Campus, the site of a former military hospital for shell-shocked officers during the Great War. It will include musical performances from George Watsons College Symphony Orchestra and Scottish fiddlers.Meanwhile, director Danny Boyle is asking people to gather on beaches across the UK on November  and etch silhouettes in the sand "remembering the millions of lives lost or changed forever by the conflict".Events will take place at low tide at a number of beaches, including St Ninians beach in Shetland, Perranporth in Cornwall and Clacton-on-Sea in Essex.Battles Over ndash a series of hundreds of local events to mark the centenary of the Armistice ndash will also be held across the country today.Pipers will play, beacons will be lit, and church bells will ring in all corners of the UK and around the world as communities pay tribute to the First World War fallen.Silhouettes of soldiers from the First World War have also been projected on to famous UK landmarks, including Edinburgh Castle, the Marble Arch and Titanic Belfast.The silhouettes have appeared all over the UK since the campaign launched in February, commemorating the British and Commonwealth troops who died in the First World War while also raising funds for military charities.One of the largest overseas gatherings to mark Armistice Day will be in France, where president Emmanuel Macron will host German chancellor Angela Merkel and dignitaries from  countries.Americans will remember those who fought alongside French and British Empire troops on the Western Front from  onwards with a ceremony in the National Cathedral in Washington. Events will also be held in Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.Munich hosted a European Requiem ndash music from across the continent ndash on Saturday. Today, in Karlsruhe, there will be an ecumenical church service, with visitors from Coventry attending.Later this month, Germans mark their own sombre commemoration of the victims of all conflict and oppression, Volkstrauertag. Old soldiers and others wear a blue cornflower to remember those who lost their lives.

title: armistice-100-nicola-sturgeon-lays-wreath-in-edinburgh
story: Thousands of people across the country observed a two-minute silence at am in recognition of the centenary of the Armistice and those who lost their lives during the war.Many did so as they attended ceremonies, parades and services, others pausing for reflection in locations such as railway stations - echoing acts of remembrance taking place across the UK on this day of commemmorations globally.She did so after  rounds were fired from Edinburgh Castle, with the guns then falling silent.Of the , Scots who joined the forces, more than , died during the First World War.Nearly every village, city and town in Scotland has some form of memorial displaying the names of their war dead.Speaking ahed of the ceremony, Ms Sturgeon said: "Remembrance Sunday is an opportunity for people in Scotland to join with others across the world to commemorate those who made the ultimate sacrice in conflicts during the last century."It allows us a chance to honour the memory of those who gave their lives, while also paying tribute to our veterans and those who continue to serve today."This year of course has added poignancy as it marks  years since the signing of the Armistice that ended the First World War."The laying of a wreath is a small but signicant tribute, and I am privileged to be able to do so on behalf of the people of Scotland."More than  wreaths were being laid at the poignant service, organised by Legion Scotland and attended members of the Armed Forces, and representatives of the emergency services and faith organisations.Later in the day, Ms Sturgeon and the Princess Royal will join around , people attending a national service at Glasgow Cathedral to mark the end of the Great War.A two-minute silence was being observed at am at the cenotaph in Glasgows George Square, as it was at war memorials in communities large and small around the country.Musicians and artists have also come together to commemorate the milestone.Before sunrise, inidual pipers at locations around the world, including a number in Scotland, performed Battles Oer, a traditional song played at the end of conflicts.Six Scottish beaches are taking part in filmmaker Danny Boyles UK-wide event to mark the centenary.St Ninians Isle beach in Shetland, West Sands in St Andrews, Scapa beach in Orkney, Ayr beach, Burghead Bay beach on the Moray Firth and Cula Bay beach on the isle of Benbecula in the Outer Hebrides all have a large-scale portrait of a casualty from the conflict drawn in the sand before it is washed away by the incoming tide.Mr Boyle said: "Beaches are truly public spaces, where nobody rules other than the tide. They seem the perfect place to gather and say a final goodbye and thank you to those whose lives were taken or forever changed by the First World War."After dark, a special light and sound projection will take place at the Scottish Parliament, with the names of all those Scots who died during the conflict to be beamed on to the building.It will take seven hours, from pm until midnight, for the names of each of the , men and women to be shown.Beacons of fire will be lit at points around Scotland and the rest of the UK during Armistice Day in a National Trust project.Buildings and landmarks across the country have also been showing their support for the Scottish Poppy Appeal by lighting up red in the week running up to, and including, Remembrance Day.

title: scotland-ends-armistice-day-services-at-glasgow-cathedral
story: Princess Anne and Vice Admiral Sir Tim Laurence, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and Glasgows Lord Provost Eva Bolander were among those who attended the service in Glasgow Cathedral on Sunday afternoon.The multi-generational tribute featured young people and representatives from across the Commonwealth and included First World War songs as well as traditional hymns.Read more:Remembrance Sunday: How Scotland marked Armistice The service came on a day of commemorations around the country with ceremonies, parades and services taking place to pay tribute to those who have lost their lives in conflict.The service in Glasgow, organised by WW Scotland in conjunction with Glasgow City Council, focused on the four key themes of sadness and relief, joy and victory, seeds of change and courage for the future.Attendees gather outside Glasgow Cathedral Professor Norman Drummond, chairman of WW Scotland, said the commemorations had taught people to use memory as a "tool for living".He said: "In these uncertain times weve realised that while attitudes may have changed there are certain values which are timeless - loyalty and devotion, courage and self-sacrice and perseverance, demonstrated by those who, for our tomorrow, gave their le.Read more: Watch drone footage unveil incredible World War One sand portrait"What better tribute can we give to those who went before us than by continuing to demonstrate those values in our daily le."The service, narrated by ex-Royal Marine, TV presenter and athlete JJ Chalmers, opened with Orcadian musician Andy Cant playing a specially commissioned fiddle tribute entitled Glimmers of Goodbyes.The National Youth Choir of Scotland, Glasgow Cathedral Choir and Legion Scotland singer Amy Hawthorn led the congregation in a musical repertoire that included hymns and songs such as Pack Up Your Troubles In Your Old Kitbag and Keep Right On To The End Of The Road, written by Harry Lauder after his son John was killed in the conflict.The WW Scotland Armistice Centenary Prayer, composed by Professor Drummond, was read by three generations of a German Scottish family, along with Commonwealth representatives from Canada, Australia and New Zealand.Children featured in the service, with Cara Lucas, , from Peebles, reading the Prayer of St Francis.Her father, Alexander James Lucas, was a Royal Marine Commando serving with  Commando based in Arbroath, when he was killed in action in Kajaki on November  , aged .Princess Anne was handed a posy by Iona and Torrin Scott-Elliot, the great-great-grandchildren of Lieutenant Colonel William Herbert Anderson who was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross after he died in the conflict, as did his three brothers.Nicola Sturgeon arrives at Glasgow Cathedral First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "Today was a very fitting and poignant service as we leave a legacy for future generations on the history and horrors of World War One."It is hard for us to imagine exactly how people would have felt one hundred years ago."There would no doubt have been elation and relief that the war had finally ended, but the loss of so many lives and the injuries sustained had a lasting impact on families and communities - an impact which current and future generations must never forget."Earlier in the day, Ms Sturgeon laid a wreath at the Stone of Remembrance outside Edinburghs city chambers, where more than  wreaths were laid, while large crowds gathered for wreath-laying ceremonies in Glasgow and Aberdeen.

title: a-day-of-memory-and-hope-from-the-pipes-at-sunrise-to-the-last-flame-of-the-night
story: The words at the service were powerful too. Professor Norman Drummond, the former army chaplain who chaired the Scottish First World War commemorations , made it clear in his address that the service, attended by over , people including Princess Anne and the First Minister, was not just about then, but now as well. The memory of the Great War, he said, was a tool for the living and a warning not to let politics get out of hand. No one referred to anything ndash or anyone ndash specic, but the congregation will have had their own ideas about what he could mean.The service had started in the light at pm and ended in the dark an hour later in a day full of symbols. At am, pipers played laments all over the country, at .am cathedral bells began to ring out and at am, thousands of Scots made the traditional gesture of silence, which this year was given added poignancy because it marked what came to be called the Great Silence: the days and weeks after the guns stopped on November , .The service at Glasgow Cathedral was the focal point of the day and, in words and music, concentrated on four themes: first, sadness at the loss of lealso, the sense of victory against the odds and the seeds of social change ndash the congregation was reminded that the Glasgow rent strikes happened just a short walk from the cathedral.The fourth theme was one that perhaps some might feel less certain about in uncertain times: courage for the future. In his prayer, Professor Drummond quoted the Canadian medical officer Lieutenant Colonel John McCrae: ldquoTo you from failing hands we throw the torch be yours to hold it high. That torch of hope and love, said Professor Drummond, continues to be thrown to each and every one of us, in our homes and in our families, in our communities and across the nation. But the torch is not as bright in some places as others, the places where war is still happening,  years later.One of the next generation taking the torch symbolically at the cathedral was ten-year-old Cara Lucas from Peebles who read the prayer of St Francis of Assisi. ldquoLord make me an instrument of your peace she said, but the words were especially poignant because Cararsquos family knows peace is far from being sorted yet: Cararsquos father Alexander James Lucas was a Royal Marine Commando when he was killed in action in Afghanistan on November , . He was  years old.Cararsquos reading was among the many words of peace and hope in the service, but there were also reminders of the greatest tragedies. Such as the fact the signing of the armistice did not immediately mean the end of the killing. It was signed very early in the morning but a few hours later, at .am, trooper George Ellison of the th Royal Lancers died near Mons. He is the last known British soldier to be killed. Scottish battalions also continued to be involved in operations until  and in southern Russian until .The music at the service reflected the desire, or duty, to remember these stories ndash at one point the Glasgow Cathedral Choir, their voices beautully filling the nave, repeated one refrain ldquowe will remember them. And the service reflected how valuable music was to the men in the trenches by including Pack Up Your Troubles in Your Old Kit Bag. The bit in the song about lighting your fag may not have quite the resonance it once had, but it was one of the most moving moments of the service when the congregation sang the song in  just as men would have done in the trenches in .The music also focused on particular stories ndash like John Lauder, the son of the great Scottish entertainer Sir Harry Lauder. Soloist Amy Hawthorn and the congregation sang perhaps Lauderrsquos most famous song Keep Right on the End of the Road. The words are still inspiring, especially when sung by a thousand people: ldquo yoursquore tired and weary still, journey on til you come to your happy abode. But the congregation was reminded why Sir Harry wrote it: his son was killed in action in December . Sir Harry decided the show had to go on and ed to the stage just a few days later.The congregation at Glasgow also included the descendants of some of those who died in the war, including the family of four Glasgow brothers, including William Herbert Anderson who was awarded the Victoria Cross. Lieutenant Colonel William Herbert Anderson, known as Bertie, was commanding the th Battalion, The Highland Light Infantry, as it moved through France in March . He was awarded the VC for leading his command in a double-counter attack, successfully driving the enemy away despite being overwhelmingly outnumbered. However, his bravery cost him his le and he died behind enemy lines on  March  at the age of .Bertie was the last of four brothers to perish in the war ndash Charlie had died on  December  at the age of , followed by Ronnie on  October  at the age of . Both had also served in the Highland Light Infantry. A week before Bertiersquos death, his youngest brother Teddie, who had transferred to the Royal Flying Corps, went down in a plane over Winchester on  March  aged just .Bertiersquos great-grandson, Robin Scott-Elliot, who attended the commemoration with his we Karen and their daughters Iona and Torrin, said he had always found it hard to imagine what his ancestors suffered.ldquoItrsquos unthinkable what the parents of Bertie, Charlie, Ronnie and Teddie must have gone through, losing all four sons in less than four years, he said. ldquoWhen I think about when they died in relation to my age now, Irsquom struck by how truly short their lives were.ldquoThe impact of their deaths was felt in the family for years ndash their parents never recovered, and my grandfather, who was a toddler at the time of Bertiersquos death, had to go through le without a father - an experience which was shared by many after the war.ldquoI am very proud of the brave actions of my great-grandfather and great-uncles. Itrsquos so important to pass these stories on to the next generation so that the devastation caused by the war is never forgotten.Iona Scott-Elliot, aged , great-great granddaughter of Bertie, added: ldquoI think we should always try to remember my great-great grandad and all the other men and women like him even though they died a long time ago.It would be hard to put it better than Iona did, but the Glasgow service did succeed in pointing out that the centenary commemorations have to be about more than remembering.The service reminded the congregation, and the audience watching on BBC, that amongst the troops at the front line there was relief at having survived but there was also anger and resentment too about what they had been put through.Some good came from that anger and restlessness ndash the vote was extended to all men over and to women over . But the service reminded us too that the lessons of the Great War were not immediately learned ndash there was a determination to be as hard as possible on the Germans in the peace negotiations after the war - and so - as we know - the seeds of the Second World War were sewn.This concern about how we learn the lessons of war and peace was reflected in one of the most powerful readings by Gurjit Singh Lali, a member of the Scottish commemorations . He quoted Gandhi: ldquoI am a man of peace, I believe in peace but I do not want peace at any price. I do not want the peace that you find in the grave. There were also words from King George V speaking in Flanders in . ldquoCan there be more potent advocates of peace upon the earth, he asked, ldquo than this massed multitude of silent witness to the desolation of war Norman Drummond explored similar themes in his address. Four years ago, when the commemorations began and a service was held in Glasgow Cathedral in , Professor Drummond asked an important question: what have we learned from all this  There were some who were critical of the idea of four years of remembrance and still are. Others asked whether it was right for then PM David Cameron to spend poundmillion on the commemorations. Part of the justication was that we should learn from the past and teach future generations, but four years on, Professor Drummond, and everyone , is still trying to find an answer to his question: what have we learned from all this In his address to the congregation, Professor Drummond said personal connections to war were important and had become more important over the last four years ndash cupboards were opened, boxes found, and letters from a century ago read and re-read. But Professor Drummond said he had learned that certain values are timeless ndash loyalty, devotion, courage, resilience. The lesson was to be there for each other ndash to be the stretcher bearer, in war and peace, for those in any kind of need.The final words of the service and the final powerful symbol went to the Right Revd Susan Brown, the moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland. Mrs Brown admits herself that she is not a big woman, but her voice was big in a cathedral that was bigger. Remember the poppy, she said. The black at its centre is the blackness of war. The red of its leaves is the red of blood. But most important of all is the green of its stem, she said, because that is the green shoot of hope.And the last bit of music in a service of music  That went to Andy Cant, who started the service with his violin high up in the roof of the cathedral. For the closing moments, he switched to the pipes and ended Scotlandrsquos act of remembrance with a wordless gesture that was perhaps its most moving. A lone piper sounding out clearly, powerfully and hopefully.The service at the cathedral was the centrepiece of a poignant day of remembrance that started before the sun came up. The first act of commemoration was at am when pipers across the country, standing in the dark, played Battlersquos Orsquoer, the traditional lament that is often heard at the end of war.Many of the pipers played at their local war memorial, but the lament was also heard at the Forth Bridge, and Cpl McClintock of Sqn ATC had the honour of piping Battles Orsquoer at the tomb of the Unknown Warrior in Westminster Abbey. The lament was also heard at Ibrox Stadium.Just a few hours later, at .am, the bells of Dunblane Cathedral were rung to mark the moment  years ago when the bells were rung at the end of the war. Across the day, church bells were also rung in Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Glasgow, Inverness and Stirling ndash some by new bell-ringers recruited over the last year to commemorate the , British bellringers who died between  and .There were other, new ways to remember too, starting at Ayr beach in the morning. Slowly, as a group of volunteers worked away on the sand yesterday, a face emerged, only to be washed away later by the tide. The face on Ayr beach was of Walter Tull, the first black officer in the British Army and one of British footballrsquos first black players. Tull had signed for Rangers when he was  but was killed while engaged in combat near Arras in Northern France. Yesterday, the sea slowly erased the sand-painting of his face as a reminder of his sad loss.Similar events were staged at other beaches across the UK, including West Sands at St Andrews, where they commemorated Elsie Inglis, a pioneering surgeon and suffragist. Other beaches taking part in the project in Scotland were Scapa beach, Orkney, St Ninianrsquos beach, Shetland, Roseisle beach, Moray, and Culla Bay on Benbecula.The beach events were the idea of the filmmaker Danny Boyle, who said they seemed the perfect place to reflect some of the consequences of the Great War. ldquoBeaches are truly public spaces, where nobody rules other than the tide, he said. ldquoThey seem the perfect place to gather and say a final goodbye and thank you to those whose lives were taken or forever changed by the First World War.The beach remembrance events happened throughout the day but it was at am that most of the country took part. The Armistice was signed in  in Compiegne and came into force on the th hour of the th day of the th month and at the same time  years later politicians, civic leaders, veterans and relatives gathered to mark the centenary at the symbolic centres of remembrance across the country.At the Cenotaph in London, the Prince of Wales led the Royal Familyrsquos tributes as the Queen looked on from a balcony. Charles laid a wreath on behalf of his mother for the second year in a row, while an equerry laid a wreath on behalf of the Duke of Edinburgh.In a signicant and hopeful break with history, the President of Germany, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, was also present and laid a wreath on behalf of the German people. It is the first time since the Cenotaph was inaugurated in  that a representative of the country has taken part in the UKrsquos national service of remembrance.At am precisely, the traditional two minutes of silence was held, but there was also a signicant and welcome sound: the chimes of Big Ben. The clock is being renovated and has been silent since August  when works began, but it has been fitted with a custom-built electronic mechanism built to power the striking hammer to ensure it can still sound for important national events.In Scotland, the am silence was observed at the Cenotaph in Glasgowrsquos George Square, while in Edinburgh First Minister Nicola Sturgeon laid a wreath at the Stone of Remembrance outside the City Chambers.Following the service, the city then thanked those who served with a procession from St Gilesrsquo Cathedral to the steps of the Scottish National War Memorial at Edinburgh Castle. The memorial houses and displays the rolls of honour of Scots servicemen and women from all the armed services, the Dominions, Merchant Navy, Womenrsquos Services, Nursing Services and civilian casualties of all wars.By the time darkness fell after pm, the remembrance took on a new shape at the Scottish Parliament when the names of the , men and women from the rolls of honour were projected on to the building. Along with Scottish servicemen, the names included nurses, munitions factory workers, Merchant Navy personnel, and overseas servicemen.The scale of the loss was reflected by the fact it took seven hours to show all the names, finishing around midnight. Each name shone on the building for around  seconds to the sound of Sir John Blackwood McEwenrsquos String Quartets Volume  by the Chilingrian Quartet. There were also images and designs that tell the story of the global war.The presiding officer Ken Macintosh said it was a striking tribute. ldquoThe fact it will take seven hours to project the names of all those who died reflects the sheer scale of the loss and devastation the warhad on communities right across Scotland, he said.The parliamentrsquos tribute was not the only light of hope and peace that shone into the dark evening. Shortly before pm, Shetlander Geoffrey Priest made his way to Saxa Vord, in the north of Unst, where he lit a beacon that was the centrepiece of the islandrsquos commemoration of the centenary. It is no surprise that Shetland would want to mark the sombre occasion, as  Shetland men lost their lives in the First World War ndash a higher proportion than anywhere  in Britain.Finally, the day and night of commemoration came to an end at .pm when an audience of around  filled the Usher Hall in Edinburgh for a performance of the multimedia production Far, Far from Ypres, which brings the story of prototypical Scots soldier Jimmy McDonald to le through songs, poems and real stories.The show featured large screen projection of images from the war and a cast of folk singers who remained on stage throughout the performance, singing the lsquotrenchrsquo, lsquomarchingrsquo and Music Hall songs of the time.Jimmyrsquos story brought the day of remembrance to an end and there was then a chance for Professor Norman Drummond to reflect on what has been learned over the last four years.Professor Drummond told The Herald that he wanted the last four years of commemoration to reflect a theme of reconciliation but also education.ldquoWhen I was invited by the Scottish Government to chair and set up the Scottish Commemorations Panel, I accepted on three conditions ndash that it would concentrate on education, genealogy and legacy and we asked: what do we learn from all this  he said. "I think the Scottish commemorations have been pivotal in reminding us that this is not just remembrance ndash important though that is ndash but itrsquos about what we take forward to the future.ldquoWe live in ided times and I think the First World War gives us evidence of what happens when we let politics get out of hand.Professor Drummond and his family have also felt the last four years personally. His grandfather Norman Walker, who served on the Western Front, where he was badly gassed, was awarded the MC in . Later, he was an international cricketer and played for Scotland ndash all on one lung.ldquoI was about seven or eight when he died, said Professor Drummond, ldquobut I can identy with those who wish they could talk to those who are no longer with us, to ask them: what was it really like Professor Drummondrsquos we Elizabeth also has personal connections to the conflict through her grandfather John Burn, of the Tyneside Scottish, serving with the Northumberland Fusiliers. He was killed on the th September  and, earlier this year, Professor Drummond and his we went out to Johnrsquos grave in France.ldquoThere we were, he said, ldquo years on, around one grave almost to the hour of when he would have been killed.Professor Drummond said he wanted the day to reflect four themes ndash the first being a collective sadness at the loss of le. Historians still argue about the precise number of Scots who lost their lives but we can safely say that over , died.And it was particularly poignant on the centenary of the end of the war to note that many soldiers died on the last day itself, including  Scots.The second theme was victory and Professor Drummond acknowledged that it was not just about joy but profound mixed emotions.He also hopes that the commemorations over the last four years have struck the right tone. He said: ldquoWersquove always tried to have the appropriate tone and the advice wersquove received is that, yes, the victory was important at that time ndash therefore, we commemorate it from a long lens. But there was joy and relief that it was all over and that we had withstood overwhelming odds and were really proud of the way our men and women responded.The third theme was seeds of change ndash an effort to reflect the fact that the First World War led, in the short and longer term, to economic, social, cultural and political changes.

title: wind-turbines-generating-98-of-scotlands-electricity-demand
story: WWF Scotland said that National Grid demand for the month was ,, MWh and that almost all of this could have been provided by wind turbines, which provided record levels of power.Turbines generated the equivalent of % of all Scotlands electricity demand or enough to power nearly five million homes last month, the group said.Read more:End oil and gas and hit the worst emitters hard ndash how Scotland could fight climate changeThe best day was October  when turbines generated ,. MWh, enough to power . million homes or % of households, according to WWF Scotland analysis of data from WeatherEnergy.Demand that day was ,.MWh and wind generation was % of that.Dr Sam Gardner, acting director at WWF Scotland, said: "What a month October proved to be, with wind powering on average % of Scotlands entire electricity demand for the month, and exceeding our total demand for a staggering  out of  days."These figures clearly show wind is working, its helping reduce our emissions and is the lowest cost form of new power generation.Read more:Scottish Power to use % wind power after selling off last coal and gas stations"Its also popular, with a recent survey also showing more and more people support turbines in rural areas."Thats why its essential that the UK Government unlocks market access for onshore wind at a time when we need to be scaling up electrication of heat and transport."The worst day was October  when generation was ,.MWh, enough to power ,, homes, % of households.On  days generation was over % of households while on  days generation was more than % of demand.The majority of the turbines were onshore, with offshore ones accounting for .% of output in October.Alex Wilcox Brooke, weather energy project manager at Severn Wye Energy Agency, said: "Octobers figures are a prime example of how reliable and consistent wind production can be, with production on  days outstripping national demand."The data comes from WeatherEnergy, part of the European EnergizAIR project which is supported by the Intelligent Energy Europe Programme and led by the European Agency for Competitiveness and Innovation.Severn Wye Energy Agency is the UK partner.

title: ministers-prepare-to-claw-back-public-funds-if-michelin-factory-closes
story: Almost  workers face losing their jobs at the factory, which has been a feature of the cityrsquos manufacturing landscape since .Economy Secretary Derek Mackay said he was looking at "every possible avenue of support" to find a viable solution to protect as many jobs as possible.He revealed pound. million of public funding would be clawed backMichelin pushed ahead with the closure.Mr Mackay was in Dundee for the first meeting of an ldquoaction group of politicians, industry experts and union leaders tasked with saving the factory.He said the group was ldquoworking really hard, really energetically to try and get the best outcome we can by putting a case to Michelin to stay in Dundee.But he insisted: ldquoWe donrsquot want to give  hope. We donrsquot want to raise expectations beyond whatrsquos achievable.He said: ldquoThere is the sense still of disappointment at Michelinrsquos decision to close the plant, and they have made it clear to me that they donrsquot wish to revisit that decision.ldquoWhat they are interested in is the proposition that we can put to them. John Reid, who is the local plant manager, said itrsquos unprecedented for Michelin to give such a hearing."He said Michelin had described the actions of the Scottish Government as "the most constructive and positive that theyrsquove ever had" given the circumstances.He added: ldquoSo the mood is one of disappointment at Michelinrsquos decision, but actually some hope that we can salvage something from this decision that will ensure that Michelin has a future [in Dundee], and protect those  workers at all costs.Optionsbeing considered includepumpingmore public money into the factoryor handing Michelin a tax break. One way forward could be to refocus the plant towards research and development.But Mr Mackay dismissed suggestions a recent hike in business rates had played a part in the threatened closure. Michelin has seen its tax bill rise by more than pound, over the last five years.He said: ldquoRight now, we have an unprecedented opportunity to present a proposition to Michelin to stay.ldquoThatrsquos what the workforce expect, thatrsquos what the city expects, and thatrsquos what Irsquom focused on.Scottish Enterprise handed Michelin pound.m of a wider pound.m grant to modernise its Dundee plant last year. It followed similar payments in previous years.Mr Mackay said the most recent grant would be recoupedthe site closed. It is understood it had conditions attached which included maintaining jobs.Michelin previously agreed to consider any proposals brought forward before the end of the month.Speaking after Mondays meeting, Mr Mackay reiterated his call for the UK Government to commit an additional poundmto the Tay Cities Deal, aimed at bringing long-term investment to the area.Holyrood ministers have pledged poundmto the scheme, but their counterparts down south have failed to match this and promised just poundm.Scottish Secretary David Mundell insisted the commitment from UK ministers represented ldquoa very signicant contribution to the future of the local economy.He said: ldquoWe have been very clear that itrsquos not a competition. We took forward the proposition that we did on the basis of the projects and the situation that we found ourselves."It came as Mr Mundell announced a poundminvestment in Dundees world-leading games industry.Devastated workers at Michelinrsquos Baldovie complex were told they faced losing their jobs last week.It came as a devastating blow to a city which recently celebrated the opening of the pound million VA design museum.Nicola Sturgeon has pledged to leave ldquono stone unturned as ministers scramble to save the site.Michelin, which is the largest industrial employer in Dundee, blamed a struggling market and cheap imports for its decision.Dundee City Council leader John Alexander said he was under ldquono illusions about the struggle ahead.He said: ldquoThe reality is, the ripple effect this has is quite signicant. And at a time when we are trying to revitalise, reenergise the local and regional economy, this clearly sends the wrong message.ldquoWe are absolutely laser focused on getting a positive outcome for as many of those workers as we possibly can, and retaining a footprint for Michelin, whatever that may look like.

title: sponsored-content-discover-six-delicious-ways-to-enjoy-fresh-scottish-seafood
story: The Crinan HotelThe Crinan Hotel has been famous for the freshest seafood and a fine selection of other local produce for nearly fty years.You can choose from a range of dining options -The Westward Restaurant is just the place for a relaxing evening meal with an outstanding view out over the sea towards the islands. Enjoy the sunset with a five-course menu and coffee.The Seafood Bar has an a la carte menu which also includes chunky steaks and the best fish and chips and is perfect for lunch or dinner. On a fine day you can enjoy lunch outside overlooking the canal.At the weekends from June to September you can book a table in Lock , theSeafood Restaurant enclosed on the roof of the hotel. Looking west you can see the sun set over the Corryvreckan and the Isles of Jura and Scarba.Loch Crinan Jumbo Prawn Corryvreckan is spectacular Crinan signature dish. The combination of prawns and tropical fruit is visually amazing and tastes wonderful. Local fishing boat ldquoGolden West lands the locally caught jumbo prawns every afternoon just  metres from the hotel kitchen. The picture shows the ldquoGolden Westpassing the Hotelrsquos classic motor yacht ldquoMV Sgarbh which takes guests on boat trips to the islands during the summer months.Oysters, Jura lobster, local scallops and these magnicent prawns are served daily in the Seafood Bar and Westward Restaurant. The Crinan Hotel has some special autumn offers on now and there is still availability for the amazing Three Day House Party at New Year.The Crinan Hotel, Crinan, Lochgilphead, Argyll, PA SW -www.crinanhotelndash Telephone:  ----------------------------------------------------------------------Oban ndash Seafood Capital of ScotlandOne of the townrsquos original seafood restaurants used to proudly proclaim lsquofrom the pier to the pan as fast as we canrsquo which perfectly summed up the advantage of operating within sight and smell of the sea.Oban is built around its famous distillery which overlooks the bay and the townrsquos now equally famous seafood restaurants are but a salmonrsquos leap from the coastline with many enjoying stunning views towards Kerrera, Lismore and the Isle of Mull.If you venture inland yoursquoll still find fabulous seafood and fresh shellfish: Argyllrsquos rich sealochs stretch like fingers into the glens and produce that unique mix of salinity and peat that produces plump rope grown mussels. Oysters are plentul too, local oyster producers supply to top London and Edinburgh eateries and Obanrsquos award-winning restaurants ndash of which there are now several.There are plenty of seaborne adventures in Oban too. Go sea-fishing for giant Hake, take a whale and dolphin safari or swim with basking sharks. Learn to kayak or perfect your skills at one of several kayak schools. Paddle board or sail or just admire the many yachts and ferries. The town welcomes visitors by boat and the new step ashore short stay pontoons on North Pier make access easy for everyone. Take a day trip to one of the islands or relax and just gaze out to sea. Oban is a beautul, vibrant and friendly highland town and itrsquos closer than you think.www.oban.org.uk----------------------------------------------------------------------The Chlachain InnIn the picturesque fishing village of Mallaig, at the lsquoEnd of the Road to the Islesrsquo, there is a true Scottish hidden gem. A popular haunt with the locals for a long time, The Chlachain Inn is now a favourite for tourists and visitors to the area. Arriving by train to Mallaig on the West Highland line or by road to catch a ferry service to the Isles, visitors to the area have been flocking to the restaurant and bar for years.The West Coast of Scotland is renowned for the quality of the local seafood produce. The Chlachain Inn use the freshest seafood landed there to its full potential. They take the renowned Mallaig haddock to another taste level, as well as serving up succulent prawns, scallops and langoustines, which all come highly recommended. They serve a sumptuous seafood platter, leaving diners feeling satisfied that theyrsquove enjoyed the best the coastal seas have to offer.The restaurant is open seven days a week all day, so there is no excuse for not popping in when in the area or making a special trip just to do so. They have three rooms available to make your stay even more relaxing with neutral and calming deacutecor and en-suite walk-in showers. An overnight stay provides the perfect chance to sample the extensive range of whiskey and beers. The bar is well stocked and serves a lunch and dinner menu, ranging from snacks to homemade meals, with children welcome.The Chlachain Inn is truly an all year-round experience. Whether you visit in the summer and enjoy some al-fresco dining in their seated decking area or cosy up during the colder months, the owners and staff will provide a warm welcome.www.chlachaininn----------------------------------------------------------------------The Seafood ShackThe Seafood Shack is an outdoor catering business located in the beautul village of Ullapool on the North West Coast of Scotland.Kirsty and Fenella are two local ladies with experience of both catering and the fishing industry in Ullapool and the Highlands. Their intention with the Seafood Shack is to offer top quality seafood that is caught and landed locally.Fenella and Kirsty have had many highlights since opening the Shack, but one stands out. Last year they where delighted to win one of the BBC Food and Farming awards, the best street food and takeaway business in the U.K."The Seafood Shack aims to deliver beautully cooked seafood that has come from our waters in a manner that respects the quality of produce we are lucky to have on hand. We want to keep it good value and ensure that our customers will be happy and want to come back again and again."ldquoEach day the fishermen come in and drop off their lsquocatch of the dayrsquo which enables us to then create our daily menu. An ever changing menu has always been one of the highlights of coming to the Shack. Quite often while customers are at the Shack they get the view of fishing boats coming in and out of Ullapool and even getting to meet some of the fishermen while they drop off their catch."Dishes you would expect to see at the Seafood Shack include:Hand ed king scallops on a bed of beetroot couscous, fresh salad and a lemon and parsley butter.A fresh haddock fillet in a light tempura batter with salad, lemon mayonnaise, pesto and wrapped in a soft tortilla.Creel caught langoustines cooked whole in a garlic and thyme butter and fresh bread.Brown Atlantic crab meat with an avocado, chilli, dill and lime salad.www.seafoodshack----------------------------------------------------------------------Kilted LobsterKilted Lobster isan award-winning boutique seafood restaurant nestled in the heart of Stockbridge. Serving the highest-quality sustainably and ethically sourcedScottish seafood, game and beef, alongside delicious vegetarian, vegan and gluten free options, Kilted Lobster truly has something for every palate, with a carefully considered wine list to match.If yoursquore struggling to choose between the delicious meat and seafood options, why not sample the best of both and try the dry-aged beef fillet with creel-caught langoustines  Donrsquot forget to leave room for afters so you can sample the ever-changing Scottish cheese selection, wild Scottish berries, or perhaps one of the many Scottish gins or whiskies.NamedEthical Eating Destination  at the Scottish Food Awards and shortlisted for Seafish and Catererrsquos  Seafood Restaurant of the Year, Kilted Lobster continues to make a dference in the community by providing cookery classes, hospitality training, educational opportunities and support for those in food poverty. Kilted Lobster has become both a destination restaurant and a neighbourhood favourite.Shortlisted: Top  Best Seafood Restaurant in the UK.Winners of the Scottish Food and Drink Awards: Best Ethical Restaurant Award, real and Local Food Gold Metal Award, Highly Recommended Restaurant Award.www.facebook kiltedlobsterwww.kiltedlobster----------------------------------------------------------------------The Fish WorksThe Fish Works is a multi award winning family business run by husband and we team Ross and Tfany Irvin. Being Largs locals and working on the promenade daily, we had the idea of bringing to Largs, somewhere visitors and locals can come to enjoy fresh quality Scottish seafood in a relaxed environment with the best views of Firth of Clyde.We strive to plough all our knowledge and passion for quality into providing customers with great sustainably sourced ingredients cooked fresh made to order.We wanted to supply traditional haddock and chips in the lightest crispy batter but also twists on the traditional like fresh langoustine tails, calamari, seasonal fish from the day boats of Peterhead and childrenrsquos meals served in a bucket and spade.Being located in Scotland with over  miles of coastline surrounded by clear cold seas, we are lucky to have access to the freshest local Scottish ingredients, our fish is expertly selected from Peterhead by our Fish Merchant, our whole Langoustine are caught daily by local fisherman Ian Wightman aboard the Eilidh Anne. Our ethos is to give our customers fresh food, handmade and expertly cooked in the best traditional way.Trading only since May  we are delighted to have been nominated and won so many awards this early on, hopefully we can continue to serve great Scottish seafood and go on to win more awards.Winner of Best Fish and Chip Shop in Scotland  and Best Newcomer at the Dine In Awards Winner of Taste Our Best Scotland award  UK Top  Best Newcomer Award at the National Fish and Chip Awards Finalist Best Seafood Week Award at the National Fish and Chip Awards Finalist Best Take Away at The Scottish Entertainment and Hospitality Awards We look forward to seeing you soon,Ross and TfanyThe Fish Works TeamWebsite: www.thefishworksFacebook:en-gb.facebook fishworkslargsInstagram: @thefishworksTwitter: @fishworkslargs
